bioghist.p: Horace G. Richards (1906-1984) was a geologist at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia. He received his Ph.D. in zoology and paleontology from the University of Pennsylvania in 1932. He worked at the Smithsonian Institution and at the New Jersey State Museum before joining the Academy in 1937 as a research fellow. He became Chairman of the Department of Geology and Paleontology in 1960 and served in that capacity until his retirement in 1974. He published more than 260 scientific papers and was the author of six books on earth science and marine fossils. He was an authority on the geologic formations of the Atlantic coastal plain, and spearheaded the Academy's Atlantic Coastal Plain Project in 1947 to collect and study fossils and well samples from the Coastal Plain. Richards was also president of the Shorelines Commission of INQUA (the International Union for Quaternary Research).

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of personal and professional papers of Horace G. Richards. Materials in the collection include: Academy correspondence; trip reports, itineraries, and expense records; records of the Atlantic Coastal Plain Project (grant proposals, correspondence, reports) ; records of his work for the International Union for Quaternary Research; records of his activities as a member of professional societies, including the Philadelphia Geological Society; scrapbooks containing announcements and programs for Richard's lectures and newspaper clippings about his work and that of other Academy staff; publications (books, reprints, magazine articles); interviews and scripts for radio and television science programs; records of courses taught and some papers by his students; maps of Cape Island, Cape May County, NJ.; notebooks; Richardsâ€™ master's thesis and other student papers; and diplomas. The collection also includes photo albums, film and glass slides, and negatives taken on journeys throughout the world. There are also indexes of travel photos and indexes of photos of specimens.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
